title: Does lying turn the lie into the truth eventually? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely! During a particularly dark time, I was lonely enough to join a dating site. My first profile was bluntly honest, outlining all of my potential red flags, but also describing my better points in no uncertain terms. It bombed in spectacular fashion. A week or so later, I decided to really highlight my sense of humor, so I rewrote my profile, except … every single statement was a lie. It was done in such a blatant way that anyone with a functioning cerebral cortex would know it was in jest, and to understand the reality of me, all one had to do was simply reverse every statement. It started out something along the lines of “I have never held a job in my life, I can’t stomach children or animals, and I would never even consider raising a child on my own …” blah blah blah. It was actually pretty funny, and as you’re probably already suspecting, it had a lot more impact than the first one did. In the end, I never did get to the dating phase, so I cancelled the account. Actually, that’s not quite true. I cancelled the account because it demonstrated exactly how superficial people could be, and it was disheartening, leaving me feeling like I had even less self-worth than before I had joined. Maybe if I’d hit it off with someone I would feel differently, but in today’s world, everything and more relevantly, everyone is disposable, at least to certain people, and I wanted no part in it. Forgive my slight digression there. I should probably include those thoughts in a more relevant answer, should I stumble across one. To conclude, it’s actually quite easy to use lies to tell the truth, so long as the audience is aware of the fact. It’s when they are not that you have to be careful, lest you violate their trust.

Not quite. Something either is or is not objectively true regardless of how often you assert the opposite claim. As for “subjective truth” this question is going to make me cite a quote from someone I’d really rather not quote. “Make the lie big, make it simple, keep saying it, and eventually they will believe it.”-Adolf Hitler Unfortunately this is one point Hitler had correct. Barring the “big lie” part of the formulation, the belief of repeated assertion is an observable phenomenon known as the “Illusory Truth Effect”. Any number of common “facts” like ‘humans only use 10% of their brains’ or ‘porcupines can shoot quills up to 30 feet!’ fall under the purview of illusory truth. Many “old wives tales” like these and many others are falsely believed truths created through simple reinforcement. After all, if you hear the same thing from multiple sources then there must be some grain of truth behind it (a reasonable but fallacious assumption). In general the use of illusory truth is a key backbone of any propaganda machine. You can observe this in media today where often even in the absence of any greater agenda beyond selling content, media outlets will use confirmation bias to draw user-base/viewership and thus reinforce false narratives via illusory truth in a feedback loop of polarization and thus further media consumption to confirm further bias.

All lies bear witness to truth, ironically. In a sense, lies are used by truth as proofs because in the presence of truth lies are destroyed by their own distinction. This is what it means for darkness to be swallowed up by light. Lies are apparent facts whose apparition is only present where the contrast created by truth is obscured by opacity. Evidence itself is clarity, even in its etymology. Isaiah 9:2 NIV [2] The people walking in darkness have seen a great light; on those living in the land of deep darkness a light has dawned. Darkness speaks of the absence of light. If this were not so we could not see darkness, because no vision would exist in the beginning. Yet we have vision. Yet we have ears to hear. Even where that vision is so minimal that we have only light perception or people walking about appear like trees still that definitive dichotomy proves that truth enlightens whereas darkness is truly invisible. Lies are used by truth to display its sovereignty. In the presence of truth lies submit their testimony by their own disintegration. Their penetration causes them to pass away such that only truth persists.

It depends on your definition of ‘a lie' if it is simply untruth or if it means ‘false witness' which is lies to demean another's character or boost one's own. In 2 Samuel 12, (Bible reference) Nathan the prophet told David a ‘false story' to help him realize a significant sin in his life. In 1 Kings 22:22 an angel deceives the prophets with a lying spirit. If evil men came to take a person from your home to kill them without trial or due process and asked if they were there. You would (should) lie and send them away to protect the innocent and justice.

Yes and No. You can literally rewrite your own memories this way. People make false memories and convince people of them all the time. But, is it objectively true? probably not. Not unless you can convince EVERYONE involved of the ‘lie’ you created and change all their memories as well.

Thanks, Bill for your ask2A. Can lies be told to tell the truth? That could depend on the answer to “how much pee do you want in your cornflakes?” None … in my case, anyway. That is simple enough from my point of view, but it seems very strange to me how much that question of ethics is muddled about these days. I suspect that is due to immense structural damages incurred by society's obsesive flirtations with untruth. Just STOP that already! Conversely, can the truth be used to tell lies? Absolutely yes. A shading here and a twisting there, and the truth becomes illicitly used as a shield behind which all manner of evils are camouflaged. Discernment may have gone out of fashion in this troubled age of deception, but progress … that is not.

The definition of a lie is an intentionally false statement. To what extent does a lie become the truth? To the extent that the creator of the 'intentionally false statement' was so stupid that the intentionally false statement coincidentally happens to be true.
No. Just like two wrongs don’t make a right, a lie doesn’t make a truth. (BTW- Two Wrongs don’t make a Right, but three Rights make a Left. Try it on paper sometime to see the truth!)

Of course lies can be used to tell the truth. Look at your road map. The freeway is not red and it does not scale out to be two miles wide. These are lies. But they are useful to show the general location of the freeway and it’s critical connections to other roads. Without the lies, it would be very difficult to see the basic information that one wants from the road map.
NO, because a lie is a lie and contradictory to the truth.
Truth lines up with reality and lies don’t. Can crayons be used to create a photo?
Yes, absolutely! (or was that a lie?)
The best lie always uses parts of the truth
